div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Arkansas Democrat, January 13, 1928
div1.p:
“Sir Arthur Newsholme, former principal medical offi-
cer of the local government board of England, was asked to
list briefly the outstanding discoveries in preventive medicine
during the last 70 years,” Dr. Morris Fishbein writes. His
list included the following:

The discovery by Pasteur of the germs that cause dis-
ease.

The discovery by Lister of antiseptic methods against
germs.

The work of Robert Koch, who devised methods of grow-
ing germs and discovered the cholera organism and the germ
of tuberculosis.

Among other discoverers of germs he mentions Loeffler,
who discovered the organism of glanders in 1882; Nicolauer,
the germ of tetanus in 1884; Weichselbaum, the germ of
meningitis in 1887, and Kitasato and Yersin, the germ of
plague in 1894.

He does not forget that von Behring and Roux devel-
oped successfully the method of injecting antitoxin to com-
bat the poison of the diphtheria germ. He pays tribute to
our own Theobald Smith, whose splendid work blazed a new
path when he showed that the tick was responsible for spread-
ing Texas fever.

He tells how some of the ailments of men can be laid at
the door of the mosquito and who made that discovery. Man-
son showed that “Filaria” was carried by the mosquito.
Ronald Ross showed that malaria was carried by the same
insect, and Walter Reed and Henry R. Carter showed that
yellow fever was spread by the mosquito.

The work of Flugge, Haldane and Leonard Hill, who
demonstrated the importance of movement of air and of the
avoidance of excessive humidity in the ventilation of rooms,
also is mentioned. Ehrlich, inventor of salvarsan, of course,
is not overlooked.

This is but a partial list of that wonderful galaxy of mi-
crobe hunters who have contributed so much to man's span
of life. But the life of every one of those scientists was filled
with a romance so interesting that an evening with one of
their biographies is an evening well spent.
